_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP plans work together to assure that potential on-site hazards and off-site consequences are identified and controlled.  All 14 elements of the OSHA PSM program, the EPA requirement for developing an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA), and the RMP submittal are included within the facility's prevention program.  



DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Warden, Washington processing facility produces various potato products such as French fries of various shapes and seasonings, and formed potato products. The plant site consists of a main processing plant, raw potato storage buildings, general maintenance facility, boiler/refrigeration facility, primary water treatment facility, and refrigerated cold storage. 



The covered process at the facility is a closed loop anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems.  The ammonia refrigeration system allows the finished products to be quickly cooled and frozen.  There is one independent refrigeration systems at the facility, which has more than the Threshold Quantity (TQ) of anhydrous ammonia.  



DESCRIPTION OF THE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The OSHA PSM component elements are organized as follows: 1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program whenever possible; 2) Ammonia awareness and PSM training is provided to all employees, operators and maintenance personnel receive additional training; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on the covered process; 4) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the covered process was conducted and will be periodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the covered process will continue to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the covered process; 7) Contractors working on or near the

system are selected through a rigorous review of their safety performance and relevant experience, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job before being allowed to perform work at the facility; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted on or near the covered process could generate sparks and possibly compromise the integrity of the process; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the covered process be evaluated and approved prior to work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to restart of the covered process after modifications, to ensure the impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident Investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that could endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release, and that notifications are made to key personnel and authorities at the local, state and federal levels depending on the extent of the release; and 14) Trade Secrets do not hinder the dissemination of information regarding the covered process, to all employees.  



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases of the covered process chemical, anhydrous ammonia, at the Warden, Washington facility in the last five years 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Warden, Washington facility plans to respond to releases of the covered process chemical, anhydrous ammonia, and therefore has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP).  The ERP has been reviewed with the Warden Fire Department and the Grant County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The purpose of the plan is to establish policies and procedures for protecting th

e health and safety of employees, contractors, and visitors, and to comply with all applicable federal and state regulations.  Training of employees and contractors includes providing a copy of the plan upon initial employment at Lamb Weston, Inc. and reviewing it for their specific assignment, annual refresher training for current employees, and review for all whenever the plan is changed. In addition, plant evacuation drills are conducted on a regular basis.  The plan is comprehensive enough to deal with all types of emergencies specific to the Lamb Weston Warden, Washington facility and defines the following:



* Preferred means for reporting fires, hazardous materials incidents, medical, and any other emergencies;

* Emergency escape routes and assembly areas;  

* Procedures to account for all employees including contractors and visitors; and

* Names of agencies and persons to contact.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety systems and preventative maintenance measures will be constantly evaluated and improved.  The facility will evaluate recommendations from Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits in a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequence of an unintentional release.
